description: From Middle English ballok, from Old English bealluc (“testicle”); synchronically ball +‎ -ock.

entries.meaning: (Britain, Ireland, vulgar, chiefly in the plural) A testicle.
examples: You've got a bollock hanging out of your shorts.

verbs.description: bollock (third-person singular simple present bollocks, present participle bollocking, simple past and past participle bollocked)

entries.meaning: (Britain, transitive, vulgar, slang) To reprimand severely and grossly.
examples: The boss bollocked me for coming in late.

entries.meaning: (Britain, vulgar, slang) To exhaust, tire out.
examples: I woke at 17:05 and felt totally bollocked.  After a shower, I went to the NAAFI for some sarnies and orange juice.
